'''Vineyard Power Co-operative''' is "a community owned renewable energy co-operative based on the island of Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts."<ref>[http://corp.sec.state.ma.us/corp/corpsearch/CorpSearchSummary.asp?ReadFromDB=True&UpdateAllowed=&FEIN=001016176 The Commonwealth of Massachusetts William Francis Galvin - Public Browse and Search<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> <ref>[http://www.vineyardpower.com/ Vineyard Power Cooperative | A Community-Owned Energy Cooperative On Martha's Vineyard<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Vineyard Power develops local renewable energy projects and plans to assist the island of [[Martha's Vineyard]] to meet the energy goals of the Island Plan, and work towards a 100% renewable energy supply.<ref>[http://islandplan.org Island Plan: The Island Plan - Moving Towards Implementation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The founding of Vineyard Power was inspired by the renewable energy vision of the people of Samso island in Denmark.<ref>https://vineyardgazette.com/news/2010/02/19/vision-true-vineyard-energy-independence</ref>
==Wind Power== Offshore wind development is another of the motivations for creating the Vineyard Power Co-op, with the recognition this energy source would need community support. The National Renewable Energy Lab (NREL) classifies the sound and ocean around Martha's Vineyard to be "Excellent" (between 7.5 and 8 meters per second (m/s) in regard to energy generation potential, at 50 meters altitude) or "Outstanding" (between 8.0 and 8.8 m/s).<ref>http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy10osti/40745.pdf</ref> The first proposal for offshore wind in the area, known as Cape Wind, created significant opposition focused on the lack of community involvement, and visual impacts. https://www.nrel.gov/news/program/2011/1437.html That project obtained a lease for development in Federal waters six miles from land in Nantucket Sound. <ref>https://www.boem.gov/Massachusetts-Cape-Wind/ </ref>
Vineyard Power organized public input into the planning wind farm development off the southern shores of the island,<ref>[http://www.rechargenews.com/hardcopy/article263967.ece Tiny developer has big plans off Massachusetts - Hardcopy - Renewable energy news - Recharge - wind, solar, biomass, wave/tidal/hydro and geothermal<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> with [http://www.offshoremwllc.com OffshoreMW], and [http://www.boem.gov Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement (BOEMRE)]. This collaboration began as the Martha's Vineyard Offshore Wind Alliance (MVOWA) in 2011.<ref>[http://www.mvgazette.com/article.php?29792 Vineyard Power Cooperative Joins Partner in Bid on Wind - 4/29/11 - Vineyard Gazette Online<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The Vineyard Power Co-op signed a Community Benefits Agreement with that one developer to formalize this arrangement for mutual benefit, and to pursue better community input and economic development for the people of Martha's Vineyard. The development is now called Vineyard Wind.<ref>https://www.vineyardwind.com/in-your-community-2/</ref> The permitting process for this offshore windfarm is underway.<ref>https://www.boem.gov/Vineyard-Wind/</ref>
==Solar Power==
During the years when the Federal process for offshore wind development moved slowly, the Co-op identified opportunities to develop solar projects on the island. The first of these were solar canopies in the parking lot at the locally-owned supermaket. Benefits for more citizens came through building solar on town-owned landfills. Town of Aquinnah chose the company, after an RFP, for a solar plant.<ref>[http://www.mvtimes.com/2011/12/08/aquinnah-voters-approve-solar-array-town-landfill-8735/ Aquinnah voters approve solar array at town landfill : The Martha's Vineyard Times<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Construction was started and completed in 2012.<ref>[http://www.mvgazette.com/article.php?34565 Solar Project Gets Early Green Light - 3/30/12 - Vineyard Gazette Online<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The most recent solar project completed is on the roof of the Boys and Girls Club.<ref>https://us.sunpower.com/blog/2017/04/12/celebrate-earth-month-marthas-vineyard-sustainable-living-community/</ref>
==See also== *[[Energy law#United States]]
==100% Renewable Energy== The Co-op promotes planning and practices that reduce fossil fuel use and the replacement with renewable electricity. The first solar canopies built by the Co-op include electric vehicle chargers. The Co-op continues to support electric vehicle adoption. Leaders of island organizations met in September 2017 at the initiative of the Co-op and Environment Massachusetts to develop a vision of 100% renewable energy use for the island.<ref>https://calendar.vineyardgazette.com/event/vineyard_power_8th_annual_member_meeting#.Wu8UpNPwau4</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.vineyardpower.com/ Vineyard Power] * [http://www.islandplan.org/ Island Plan]

{{For|the ABC-TV series|Wandjina!}} [[Image:Wandjina rock art.jpg|thumb|Wandjina [[rock art]] on the [[Barnett River]], [[Mount Elizabeth Station]]]]
The '''Wandjina''' (sometimes '''Wondjina''') are cloud and rain [[spirits]] from [[Australian Aboriginal mythology]] that are depicted prominently in [[rock art]] in [[Australia]]. Some of the artwork in the [[Kimberley (Western Australia)|Kimberley region]] of [[Western Australia]] dates back approximately 4,000 years ago.
The stories of the Wandjina and the artwork depicting them remain important to the [[Mowanjum Community]] of Indigenous people.
Wandjina were the inspiration for a 1966 children's fantasy television series, ''[[Wandjina!]]'', produced by [[ABC Television]] in 1966.
==Dreamtime legends== [[Dreamtime]] stories say the Wandjina created the landscape and its inhabitants, and continue to have influence over both. When the spirits found the place they would die, they painted their images on [[cave]] walls and entered a nearby waterhole. These paintings were then refreshed by Aborigines as a method of regenerating life force.<ref> Yorro Yorro: everything standing up alive, (1993), Mowaljarlai, D, and Malnic, J., Magabala Books, pp137-139.</ref>
The Wandjina can punish those who break the law with floods, lightning and cyclones.<ref name= FloodRockArt>{{cite book | author = Flood, Josephine | title = Rock Art of the Dreamtime | year = 1997 }}</ref>
==Traditional rock artwork==
The broad-stroke artwork of the Wandjina rock art dates around 3800–4000 years ago. The emergence of this art style follows the end of a millennium-long drought that gave way to a wetter climate characterised by regular monsoons.<ref name="ENSO Evidence">{{cite journal|last1=McGown|first1=Hamish|last2=Marx|first2=Samuel|last3=Moss|first3=Patrick|last4=Hammond|first4=Andrew|title=Evidence of ENSO mega-drought triggered collapse of prehistory Aboriginal society in northwest Australia|journal=Geographical Research Letters|date=28 November 2012|volume=39|issue=22|pages=5|doi=10.1029/2012GL053916|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2012GL053916}}</ref>
The Wandjina paintings have common colors of black, red and yellow on a white background. The spirits are depicted alone or in groups, vertically or horizontally depending on the dimensions of the rock, and are sometimes depicted with figures and objects like the [[Rainbow Serpent]] or [[Yam (vegetable)|yams]]. Common composition is with large upper bodies and heads that show eyes and nose, but typically no mouth. Two explanations have been given for this: they are so powerful they do not require speech and if they had mouths, the rain would never cease. Around the heads of Wandjina are lines or blocks of color, depicting lighting coming out of transparent helmets.<ref name=FloodRockArt/>
Today, the paintings are still believed to possess these powers and therefore are to be approached and treated respectfully. Each site and painting has a name. Indigenous people of the [[Mowanjum Community]] repaint the images to ensure the continuity of the Wandjina's presence.<ref> {{cite book | author = Flood, Josephine | title = Rock Art of the Dreamtime | year = 1997 }}</ref> Annual repainting in December or January also ensures the arrival of the monsoon rains, according to Mowanjum belief.<ref> {{cite book |author1=Akerman, Kim |author2=Ryan, Judith |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Images of Power: Aboriginal Art of the Kimberley | year = 1993 }} p.12</ref>
Repainting has occurred so often that at one site the paint is over 40 layers deep. The painting style has evolved during this process: more recent figures are stockier and some now possess eyelashes.<ref> {{cite book |author1=Mulvaney, John |author2=Kamminga, Johan |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Prehistory of Australia | year = 1999 }} p.405</ref>
==Depictions on Bark== In late 1960's and early 1970's several Mowanjum artists depicted traditional Wandjina on pieces of string bark. These artworks were sold mainly through the mission at [[Kalumburu, Western Australia|Kalumbaru]]. Some of the important artists from this region include Alec Mingelmanganu<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aboriginal-bark-paintings.com/alec-mingelmanganu/|title=Alec Mingelmanganu wandjina {{!}} wondjina {{!}} sell Alec Mingelmanganu|date=2017-09-18|work=Aboriginal Bark Paintings|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en-US}}</ref>, Charlie Numbelmoore<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aboriginal-bark-paintings.com/charlie-numbelmoore/|title=Charlie Numbelmoore {{!}} Charlie Numbulbor {{!}} sell Charlie Numbelmoore|date=2017-09-18|work=Aboriginal Bark Paintings|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en-US}}</ref> and Jack Karedada<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aboriginal-bark-paintings.com/jack-karedada/|title=Jack Karedada wandjina painting {{!}} wondjina {{!}} Sell Jack Karedada|date=2017-09-18|work=Aboriginal Bark Paintings|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en-US}}</ref>. These artworks are now in major museum collections around the world. Initially as per tradition only men painted Wandjina but in the early 1970's several women artists like Lily Karedada<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aboriginal-bark-paintings.com/lily-karedada/|title=Lily Karedada wandjina {{!}} sell Lily Karedada {{!}} wanjina {{!}} wondjina|date=2017-12-22|work=Aboriginal Bark Paintings|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en-US}}</ref> and Ignatia Djangharra<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aboriginal-bark-paintings.com/ignatia-djanghara/|title=Ignatia Djanghara wandjina {{!}} sell Ignatia Djanghara {{!}} wanjina {{!}} wondjina|date=2017-12-13|work=Aboriginal Bark Paintings|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en-US}}</ref> also painted Wandjina on bark and later on canvass.
==Other depictions== In 2007, [[graffiti]] depictions of Wandjina appeared in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Western Australia]]. Styles ranged from stencil-work to a spray painted Wandjina driving a pink car. Using [[Flickr]] and [[blogs]], several people engaged in 'Wandjina watching', documenting the Wandjina graffiti they found.<ref> [http://perth.norg.com.au/2007/01/05/watching_the_wandjina/ perth.norg.com. au/2007/01/05/watching_the_wandjina/]</ref> These 'wandering Wandjina' angered and upset some Indigenous people who said that only certain of their people are permitted to depict the Wandjina, without saying who these people are.<ref> http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/wandering-wandjinas-mystery/story-e6frg13u-1111112784667</ref> A short film, ''Who Paintin' Dis Wandjina'', discussed the Aboriginal reaction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creativespirits.info/resources/movies/who-paintin-dis-wandjina.html|title=Australian Aboriginal movies, films & Indigenous DVDs|first=Jens Korff, Creative|last=Spirits|publisher=}}</ref>
Images of the Wandjina are displayed on the walls of the [[Ringwood]] Magistrates Court in Victoria; these are referenced as produced the [[National Gallery of Victoria]].
